discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
OME-protected messages don’t work with dynamic distribution lists

Selected Answer: A
this is why:
When OME is enabled, emails are encrypted based on the address book policy that is associated with the recipient. If User2 is unable to open the encrypted email, it is likely that the address book policy associated with DDG1 does not include User2 as a member. To resolve this issue, you can configure the scope of the address book policy to include DDG1 as a member, so that User2 will be able to open the encrypted email.

Selected Answer: C
C is true, because IRM encryption doesn't support dynamic distribution groups.
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/exchange/troubleshoot/mailflow/cannot-open-irm-email-dynamic-distribution-group

C is correct

https://office365itpros.com/2022/01/21/irm-dynamic-distribution-list/

D is correct~
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/exchange/security-and-compliance/smime-exo/configure-smime-exo

https://support.microsoft.com/en-us/office/encrypt-messages-by-using-s-mime-in-outlook-on-the-web-878c79fc-7088-4b39-966f-14512658f480
D should be the answer IMO

choices.C: Instruct User1 to send the encrypted email to User2.
choices.D: Configure the MIME types that are associated with the default Microsoft Outlook Web App policy.
choices.B: Instruct User2 to upgrade their internet browser.
choices.A: Configure the scope of the address book policy to include DDG1 as a member.

questions.question_text:
HOTSPOT -
A company uses Exchange Online. The company configures a shared mailbox named Shared1 for delegated access.
Delegates report that emails from February 10, 2022 through February 15, 2022 are missing from the shared mailbox.
You need to review the audit logs for the shared mailbox.
How should you complete the command? To answer, select the appropriate options in the answer area.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.
//IMG//

A company uses Exchange Online. The company configures the following retention tags:
Inbox: Delete in 365 days.
Deleted Items: Delete in 30 days.
A user receives an email on April 27, 2022 and deletes the email on May 28, 2022.
You need to determine the retention period of the email.
On which date will the email expire?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
When a user receives an email on April 27, 2022 and deletes the email on May 28, 2022, the email will be moved to the user's Deleted Items folder. According to the retention tags configured by the company, items in the Deleted Items folder will be deleted after 30 days. Therefore, the email will expire on May 28, 2022, which is 30 days after it was deleted.

Inbox: Delete in 365 days which means the email will retain for 365 days in the Inbox before being deleted.
Deleted Items: Delete in 30 days which means the email will be deleted after 30 days of moving to the deleted items folder.

So, the email will expire on May 28, 2022 which is 30 days after it was deleted, regardless of how long it was in the Inbox before being deleted.

email will expire on the same day you move it to the trash. 
Email will be deleted after 30 days by default.
I think the answer as shown - B, May 28th - is correct.

comments.content:
Examples (from that same URL):
If the user... Receives a message in the Inbox on 01/26/2019. Deletes the message on 2/27/2019. The retention tags on folder...Inbox: Delete in 365 days / Deleted Items: Delete in 30 days. The Managed Folder Assistant...Processes the message in the Inbox on 1/26/2019; stamps it with a start date of 01/26/2019 and an expiration date of 01/26/2020. Processes the message again in the Deleted Items folder on 2/27/2019. It recalculates the expiration date based on the same start date (01/26/2019). Because the item is older than 30 days, it is expired immediately.

This question is literally the same as this example - only the dates have been changed to protect the innocent!

Therefore - answer is correct as shown.

https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/exchange/security-and-compliance/messaging-records-management/retention-age
Items in the Deleted Items folder and items which may have a start and end date, such as calendar items (meetings and appointments) and tasks, are handled differently:
Email message / In the Deleted Items folder / The retention age is calculated based on... Date of delivery or creation unless the item was deleted from a folder that does not have an inherited or implicit retention tag.

I think the answer as shown (B, May 28th) is correct.

Reason:
- Item was created on April 27
- While it was in the inbox, the Inbox retention tag of 365 days applied. BUT
- When it was moved to deleted items, it would lose the Inbox retention tag, and inherit the Deleted items retention tag of 30 days. 
- On May 28th - the day it was deleted by the user - it would be 31 days old.
- It would therefore be immediately deleted on that day.

https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/exchange/security-and-compliance/messaging-records-management/retention-tags-and-policies
Moving items between folders
A mailbox item moved from one folder to another inherits any tags applied to the folder to which it's moved. If an item is moved to a folder that doesn't have a tag assigned, the DPT is applied to it.

questions.question_text:
A company has a Microsoft Exchange Server 2019 hybrid environment. The company enables Office 365 Message Encryption (OME) and journaling.
You discover that there are encrypted emails in the journaling mailbox.
You need to ensure that all journaled emails are decrypted.
Which command should you use?

discussion.content: The answer should be A - https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/exchange/enable-or-disable-journal-report-decryption-exchange-2013-help

Agreed A should be the answer - Set-IRMConfiguration -JournalReportDecryptionEnabled $true
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/exchange/enable-or-disable-journal-report-decryption-exchange-2013-help

Selected Answer: A
A is correct

Selected Answer: A
The command you should use is "Set-IRMConfiguration –JournalReportDecryptionEnabled $true". This command enables the decryption of all journaled emails in the journaling mailbox.

The Office 365 Message Encryption (OME) allows you to encrypt the messages sent out of the organization, and the journaling feature allows you to keep a copy of all sent and received messages. By default, when OME and journaling are enabled, the journaled messages will be encrypted. In order to view the contents of those messages, you need to decrypt them.

The Set-IRMConfiguration cmdlet is used to configure Information Rights Management (IRM) settings in Exchange Online and Exchange Server. By setting the JournalReportDecryptionEnabled parameter to $true, it ensures that all journaled emails are decrypted.

Selected Answer: A
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/exchange/enable-or-disable-journal-report-decryption-exchange-2013-help
Answer should be Set-IRMConfiguration -JournalReportDecryptionEnabled $true

Selected Answer: A
Answer should be Set-IRMConfiguration -JournalReportDecryptionEnabled $true

Agreed~ 
A is correct
